title: The Ideal
description: This scenario depicts the ideal defined by Georgia law

content.title: Day 1
content.text: On Day 1, you submit a public records letter to a public agency.

content.title: Day 1
content.text: Within a few minutes, you receive an email confirming receipt of your request and stating a timetable for when an invoice will be available for you.

content.title: Day 1
content.text: Later that day, the public information officer reaches out with an itemized invoice as well as an estimate of how long the request would take.

content.title: Day 1
content.text: You send over payment and your receive the documents electronically

title: City of Austell
description: This scenario depicts the ideal defined by Georgia law

content.title: Day 1
content.text: City clerk sent an interim response

content.title: Day 5
content.text: Clerk sent another response, letting me know they were waiting on the city attorney.

content.title: Day 5
content.text: Clerk sent another email later that same day with a charge estimate of $120 dollars and a timetable of two business days.

content.title: Day 6
content.text: We requested an itemized invoice of the charges.

content.title: Day 6
content.text: Clerk said invoice would be ready in the next two days and asked for a payment method

content.title: Day 6
content.text: We sent a response, letting her know we had not accepted the charges yet.

content.title: Day 7
content.text: Clerk sent the invoice showing $100 attorney charge and $20 document charge.

content.title: Day 8 (cont.)
content.text: We sent an email to the clerk with further questions about the invoice.

content.title: Day 8 (cont.)
content.text: Clerk said she originally sent email to city attorney who is paid $175 per hour.

content.title: Day 8 (cont.)
content.text: We sent a response asking if it took the lawyer more than 30 minutes to read the email and asking what documents were being gathered

content.title: Day 8 (cont.)
content.text: Clerk replied, saying the lawyer had to look up the section and send it back to her. She also said she has to build the spreadsheet

content.title: Day 19
content.text: We sent a response, asking the clerk to clarify that the attorney was checking the section to determine if the records could be released.

content.title: Day 19 (cont.)
content.text: Clerk confirmed that was the reason for the fees.

content.title: Day 19 (cont.)
content.text: We sent a response, informing the clerk that it is against state law for an agency to charge for the time it takes attorneys to advice on what records can be released.

content.title: Day 19 (cont.)
content.text: Clerk said she was not aware of the law and reduced the charge to $20.

content.title: Day 28

content.title: Day 28
